Award.AwardTitle: Coupling Experimental and Theoretical Molecular-Level Investigations to Visualize the Fate of Degradation of Organic Compounds in Aqueous Phase Advanced Oxidation Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1435926
Minakata

Coupling Experimental and Theoretical Molecular-Level Investigations to Visualize the Fate of Degradation of Organic Compounds in Aqueous Phase Advanced Oxidation Systems

The lack of an overarching management plan combined with uncertainty about the adverse human health and ecological impacts of trace amounts of known and emerging organic compounds have raised public concerns about water. These issues also present major challenges to next generation water treatment utilities dealing with de facto and planned wastewater reuse. Advanced oxidation processes that produce highly reactive hydroxyl radicals are promising technologies to control trace amounts of organic compounds. Although the initial fate of hydroxyl radical induced reactions with diverse organic compounds have been studied, the mechanisms that produce intermediate radicals and stable-byproducts are not well understood. Significant barriers remain in our understanding of complex multi-channel elementary reaction pathways embedded in peroxyl radical bimolecular decay that produce identical intermediate-radicals and stable-byproducts. The model developed in the course of this research will give researchers and policy makers the ability to predict the likely chemical by-products and alternative options to provide least adverse impact on the general public who will directly consume this water or other ecological organisms who will be exposed indirectly.

The proposed study will integrate three thrusts to discover the currently unknown fate of the three major degradation pathways. First, we will perform pulse-photolysis kinetic measurement to determine the temperature-dependent overall reaction rate constants for multi-channel peroxyl radical reactions. We will also measure the resulting byproducts using a mass spectrometry. Second, we will employ quantum mechanical theoretical calculations to determine the elementary reaction pathways and associated reaction rate constants. Third, we will then combine our kinetic measurements with our theoretical calculations to develop an agent-based model that will enable us to visualize and predict the fate of organic compounds. With explicitly assigned reaction rules and molecular behavior embedded within a simulated reaction network, the resulting agent-based model will use software agents to represent radical species and organic compounds and then simulate their interactions to predict corresponding consequences (i.e., byproducts) over time and space. Finally, experimental observations will validate the outcomes from the agent-based model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the development of our agent-based model (ABM) during the non-cost extension period, we used our theoretical and experimental findings to design and implement a proof-of-concept model that is able to replicate the concentration profile dynamics of our acetone target-compound and some transformation byproducts in a simulated UV plus hydrogen peroxide AOP reactor. We also designed this model to be easily extendible and user-friendly. For example, the model is capable of accepting a Microsoft Excel-based user-defined reaction pathway “roster” to simulate all experimentally or theoretically derived reaction pathway dynamics discovered in prior studies. We should note that, although the design of our ABM permits such investigation, at this point in our study we have only validated model results for our specific target acetone compound in a simulated UV plus hydrogen peroxide AOP. This means that our model is computationally ready to simulate reaction pathways for other target compounds but more work must be done to validate model results beyond the specific conditions of our prior experimental and theoretical work.                      

The PI also organized and conducted four hands-on laboratory demonstrations via K-12 outreach activities during this non-cost extension period, including 3 sessions to about 15 local high school students (in October 2017), 15 high school teachers on the University of Michigan Dearborn campus (February, 2018), 20 high school students from the Detroit metro area (in July 2018), and 3 sessions to about 15 local high and middle school students (in July 2018). These demonstrations included hands-on dilution exercise in the process lab and a discussion on the significance of the contamination of trace-level synthetic organic chemicals in water.  Students were made aware of the problem of chemical contamination in water and were shown how advanced water and wastewater treatment technologies can be used to address this problem.  


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Daisuke Minakata

We should note that, although the design of our ABM permits such investigation, at this point in our study we have only validated model results for our specific target acetone compound in a simulated UV plus hydrogen peroxide AOP. This means that our model is computationally ready to simulate reaction pathways for other target compounds but more work must be done to validate model results beyond the specific conditions of our prior experimental and theoretical work. Students were made aware of the problem of chemical contamination in water and were shown how advanced water and wastewater treatment technologies can be used to address this problem.
